original_title: When the Sojourner Mars Rover Nearly Ran LISP
original_content:
During the late 1980s NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) was busy developing the first ever wheeled robot that would roam the surface of Mars. Due to the long round-trip times of any signals between Mars and Earth, development of the firmware that would control the rover was a major point, with the two teams occupied with the task each picking different levels of autonomy for the rover. In a retrospective, [Ron Garrett] who worked at JPL on the more autonomy team describes his recollections.
Whereas [Ron]s team focused on creating a rover that could be provided with high-level instructions which the sophisticated LISP-based firmware would use as guidelines to navigate and operate by, the other team pursued a more limited autonomy approach whereby a human driver would use explicitly plan out the route which the rover would follow before awaiting new instructions.
Perhaps unsurprisingly, the system requirements for running LISP and the additional uncertainties and complexities with the autonomous approach, as well as testing and validating the firmware, resulted in the Sojourner Mars rover featuring the latter approach, with straightforward C-based firmware. Most of Sojourners autonomy was limited to a home return function if communication with the lander was lost, which limited both its range and operations during its 85-day extended mission.
As [Ron] covers with examples from later missions, one advantage of LISP is that it allows you to send instructions which can be interpreted (e.g. to debug the system) without having to program in such functionality explicitly. With later Mars rover missions much more of this autonomy that [Ron]s team pioneered was implemented, although C remained the language of choice for these later rovers.
Heading image: Ron Garrett standing in front of the Robbie prototype. Rocky III can be see in the lower left, and above him are Rajiv Desai and Robert Ivlev, two other members of the team. (Credit: Ron Garret)
title: マーズローバーの開発：ソフトウェアの自律性と制約
body: 1980年代後半、NASAのジェット推進研究所（JPL）は、初めて火星の表面を移動する車輪付きロボットを開発していた。信号の往復にかかる長時間の遅延により、ローバーを制御するファームウェアの開発が重要だった。それぞれが異なる自律性を選び、高度な指示を受け取り、ナビゲーションや操作のガイドラインとして使用するローバーを作ることに焦点を当てたのは[LISP言語]のファームウェア部分に取り組んだチームだった。一方、もう一つのチームはより限定的な自律性を追求し、人間のドライバーが新しい指示を待つ前にローバーがたどるルートを明示的に計画する方法を追求した。ソジャーナー火星ローバーは、LISPを実行し追加の不確実性と複雑さを伴う自律性のアプローチに対応するためにシンプルなCベースのファームウェアが採用された。ソジャーナーの自動運転は、通信がローバーと失われた場合の帰還機能に限定され、そのためにその範囲と作業を制限されていた。後のミッションでは、[Ron]のチームが先駆けとなったこの自律性の多くが採用されたものの、C言語が後のローバーの言語として選ばれ続けた。
